author: usertm
body:
To give some counterpoints:


1) Enterprise 4g/5g market is tinier than my head, and my head is pretty small.


2) They haven't won the lawsuit in Germany and haven't filed anything in USA or BRIC. Even IF (that's a big IF) Lenovo agrees to pay some lump sum it won't happen till 2021-2022 till earlist. 


3) NOK is an old company producing expensive equipment for operators. It's not a unicorn, never was and 99.999% never will be. Other companies are irrelevant, the competitors are Ericsson, Huawei, ZTE, Samsung, Cisco and bunch of smaller vendors. 


4) Not sure if video and slides = doubling down, but whatever. Dividends might be paid in 3-5 years and there's enough money and Saturn in Capricorn etc. I'll believe it when I'll see it. 


5) Boomers say a lot of things. 


AUG $5 valuation was based on assumption NOK will get a few billions from Verizon for 5g equipment. That didn't happen.


Unless NOK managed to get a few BIG contracts or significantly cut costs the 
stock is unlikely to go above $5. 


Or maybe it will, I know nothing.

author: Ready2gambleboomer
body:
It is interesting that before the 1987 crash banks and brokers raised margin maintenance to help what they thought was over speculation in of course what else?  The tech sector.  The DJIA had tripled in the previous 5 years, just like the S&P500 has in the last five. The four horseman then were INTC, MICROSOFT, CSCO, and Sun Micros Systems.

As a young retard like you guys I walked into a Schwab office on Palm Beach right down the street from Trumps Mara Lago mansion.  80 year old blue hairs were writing naked puts on the four horseman because stocks only go up. Everyday they'd walk down from their ten million dollar oceanfront mansions and meet at Schwab like a social gathering at Duke and Duke and stare at their Bloomberg terminals with glee as their puts evaporated in value.  Sound familiar?

Monday October 19 cost a few of them those mansions and some people their lives.  When A Japanese firm who had written $300 million worth of puts couldn't complete the trades Schwab almost went under due to poor risk management.   A Merrill client in Miami had taken $750K to $7 million and then after the crash he got a $500,000 margin call.  He went into the office and....people died.

[https://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/fl-xpm-1987-10-27-8702020044-story.html](https://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/fl-xpm-1987-10-27-8702020044-story.html)

tl:dr When it comes to money be careful out there kids.  It's just a way of keeping score.  GL

author: WrongWeekToQuit
body:
This is all I've done for 30 years.  Pick 3-10 high flying tech stocks, go all in, hold on for dear life for at least 10 years, reallocate to the hottest tech stocks.  The dot-com crash almost crushed me, but most everything dropped.

Now, to present the counter-argument, not only did my portfolio drop 80% during the dot-com crash, but MSFT and AMZN did NOTHING for a good ten years.  So it's not as easy as the last ten years have made it look.  You need to believe in the management and product roadmap.

Take a look at CSCO's all-time chart for a dose of reality.  The 90s were fucking amazing. 
 I made so much money off CSCO.  And then it's been a dog since the dot-com crash.  So you need to be objective about when a company has lost its edge.  I was worried about MSFT during the Ballmer years but Satya seems to have turned things around.  Same worry about AAPL when they were lost without Jobs for a while.

author: ixamnis
body:
This. I'd put roughly the same amount into both.

That said, you might want to consider putting it into an ETF called **XLK**.  **XLK** is the SPDR Technology Select ETF.  This ETF is 23.9% Apple and 20.3% Microsoft. This means, you'd be investing nearly equal amounts into both of those stocks and that would be almost half of this ETF. This would also help you diversify your holdings a little bit.

The next holdings in the ETFs portfolio include:

**V**  (VISA) - 4.29%

**NVDA** (NVIDIA) - 4.25%

**MA** (Mastercard) - 3.80%

**ADBE** (Adobe) - 2.99%

**PYPL** (Paypal) - 2.94%

**CRM** (Salesforce) - 2.80%

**INTC** (Intel) - 2.80%

**CSCO** (Cisco Systems) - 2.12%

&#x200B;

Hope this helps.

author: techmagenta
body:
Cloudflare released a product today that aims to disrupt the fundamental building blocks of the internet (SD-WAN & MPLS). SD-WAN/MPLS is an absolutely massive industry dominated by big telecom providers (AT&T, Verizon, Bharti, Cisco, Telestra etc.)  that generates insane revenue. These are the tools used for VPNs, MPLS, data center interconnects, and cloud services like AWS. It is the technology that enables to internet to run and serve as many people as it does.

I work in telecom so I understand these technologies well. Cloudflare is essentially trying to replace the current internet with the cloudflare network. I bet they can pull it off too.

author: Test-NetConnection
body:
I started out with a 2 year degree in computer science and lucked into a 38K a year job as a sysadmin. At that job I started my 4 year degree in compsci and started pursuing certifications. In 2 years years I finished my A+ and network+, which allowed me to get a new job as a server administrator for a credit union. A year into that job I got microsoft certified, and a year after that I got my security+ certification with a promotion to systems engineer. I learned everything I could at that credit union; I made their consultants obsolete by learning cisco networking and VMware administration. The following year I finished my bachelor's in computer science, and then asked the same consultants I made obsolete at the credit union for a job. That was 6 months ago, right as all this covid stuff hit.

The only reason they lost my credit union as a client was because they took the time to show me around VMware and cisco administration. They taught me just enough for me to put together a vsphere cluster in my home lab with cisco switching and routing. That was all I needed to gain the confidence necessary to stop calling them. I decided that I wanted to work with them around the time I no longer needed their help! 

I knew it was risky going from a secure job as a Systems engineer at a credit union to an IT consultant for a small firm, but it was totally worth it. I wake up when I want to and work when I want to. I need to bill 15 hours a week to pay for myself and make the firm some extra money. Anything extra just makes me look good! Now I'm VMware certified and working on Citrix and Cisco certifications. I love all of my colleagues and the constant learning opportunities. I wouldn't trade my current job for anything.

Tldr: Never stop learning. Aim for a new certification every year, and make sure to network!

author: ralphynader
body:
**How can a feature in its infancy, increase ZM's valuation by more than the total worth of huge established companies?** It didn't increase its valuation, it increased its market capitalization.  Its valuation would be the present value of expected future cash flows.  

**So why should ZM rise 14%?**  Zoom has much higher short volume ratio, probably got squeezed.  

**How will ZM's growth continue to explode after the pandemic is over?** There is only so much market share available.  It would be foolish to think that they will crash without sustaining the same levels of absurd growth.  They already have 43% of market share..  

**Pfizer just announced its vaccine may be put in use as early as late November.**  Video conferencing is used constantly in the office.  I was on 4-5 Zoom calls a week at my office before the pandemic and we didn't even have Zoom.  

**When people finally realize the future is not that rosy for ZM?**  Do you think the CEO of Zoom feels the same way?  They went up against Cisco and Microsoft and won.  And now they have a lot of money.

author: bimm42
body:
When I look up those three mutual funds it looks like they have the same top holdings...weird.  If this is in a tax advantaged account like an IRA you might want to swap out those high expense ratio mutual funds and bulk up the holdings of the Vanguard ETFs that you have and maybe some VTI or VOO.    
What is FIDS?  I don't see any results when I look up that ticker.  
The top 3 holdings in TDIV are IBM INTC CSCO which are all companies that have not been doing well lately.  Trying to get dividends out of tech stocks is sort of an oxymoron.  Take a look at SCHD instead of TDIV.  
On another note, your dad is the man!  Great job getting you on your way.

author: adayofjoy
body:
Not the absolute fastest, but I'mma give a try with the minimum number of trades without resorting to obscure penny stocks. Also doesn't take into account dividends but who cares about those.

Feb 16, 1990 - CSCO stock is worth $0.04. Buy 20 CSCO stock with your $1.

April 7, 2000 - Sell CSCO stock at dot com bubble peak at $74.63. You now have 20 x $74.63 = **$1,492.60**.

June 16, 2000 - Buy ATVI stock at $0.51. 2926 shares purchased. Sell on May 17, 2002 at $4.13 a share for a total of 2926  $4.13 = **$12,084.38**.

April 17, 2003 - Buy AAPL stock at $0.20 a share. 60,421 shares purchased. Sell on December 28, 2007 at $6.16 for 60,421  $6.16 = **$372,193.36**.

December 1, 2008 - Buy AGQ (x2 leveraged silver, finally some leveraged products) at $63 a share. 5,907 shares purchased. Sell on April 1, 2011 at $717.92 a share for 5,907  $717.92 = **$4,240,753.44** (Million dollar mark).

November 11, 2011 - Buy AAL at $4.20 per share. 1,009,703 shares purchased. Note that I'm ignoring the fact that you have enough money to noticeably move the market now. Sell on January 5, 2015 at $51.04 a share for 1,009,703  $51.04 = **$51,535,241.12**.

February 12, 2016 - Buy SVXY (Short VIX) for $65.16 a share. 790,903 shares purchased. Sell on January 12, 2018 at $552.76 a share for 790,903  $552.76 = **$437,179,542**.

February 9, 2018 - Buy TWLO (Twilio Inc) for $24.52 a share. 17,829,508 shares purchased. Sell on July 26, 2019 at $149.95 a share for 17,829,508  $149.95 = **$2,673,534,724** (Billion dollar mark)

February 19, 2020 - Buy TVIX (Double leveraged VIX) for $39.25 a share. 68,115,534 shares purchased. Sell on March 18, 2020 at $1,000 (touched that price during intra-day trading) for 68,115,534  $1,000 = **$68,115,53**4,000

March 18, 2020 - Buy NVAX for $10.65 a share. 6,395,824,788 shares purchased. Sell on August 10, 2020 for $178.51 a share for 6,395,824,788  $178.51 = **$1.1417187e+12**

There's your fuggin trillion.

author: sweetleef
body:
> If you wheel on solid underlyings that pay divs, you pretty much can't lose if you have even a modicum of patience.

Maybe, if your timeframe is 2018-2020.  But there were plenty of "solid" underlyings that shit the bed in 00/01, and didn't get anywhere near back to their highs for 10, 15, even 20 years (e.g., MSFT, PFE, GE, F, ORCL, CSCO, etc.).  Many still haven't recouped their 00 highs.

20 years takes a bit more than a "modicum" of patience, and it takes a shitton of dividends to make up for a 50-75% price decline.

Depending on timing, you pretty much can lose.

author: Lie-Minimum
body:
My whole point is people invest in nosebleed valuation companies that are slick orators. Facebook, Amazon, google, Tesla, nvidia, etc. 

Companies like IBM, INTC, CSCO, etc. are ignored Because they aren’t showmen and don’t use buzzwords to invigorate their investors. Although I myself wouldn’t buy those three because they’re just too big to grow (I prefer companies like AMOT, CVCY, ACU, RFIL, and AMNF because they’re still very small and have room to actually be multibaggers plus it gives me the prospect of being a big shareholder one day).

I’m just arguing they’re not flashy and therefore investors don’t think they’re cool.

author: Jonnydoo
body: Aiyah, fuckin CSCO and CVX just fucking me all month.

author: obviouslybait
body: As a Cisco Certified Network Engineer, I can tell you that there had been a TON of competition in the space, they are still popular in enterprise, but white-box solutions, competition in cloud-networking space makes their absolutely absurd costs seem less appealing.

author: FinndBors
body:
I was going to post this. Also in the dot com boom -- remember the backdrop when people were buying all this stuff. The backdrop was the internet was new and going to eventually take over our lives (which was true, but did not necessarily mean that internet related companies will win).

* Sun Workstations (made servers that powered big sites of the time).
* Worldcom, Quest Communications, L3 networks -- big network providers. Worldcom went bankrupt, quest & l3 got acquired later for I believe much less than their peak.
* As mentioned CSCO, profitable built the hardware that was critical for the backbone of the internet. Other companies existed too like Juniper (200 at peak, now only 20), JDS Uniphase (now kind of defunct)
* A huge number of DSL related equipment / software makers.

These are only off the top of my head, a lot of these guys were very profitable during dot-com. Don't be so complacent about "it can't happen again".
